The "reverse hamburger bun sign" was first described by Newman et al. in 1995. It is an apparent sign of pneumonia seen in a frontal chest radiograph. The sign is produced by a circular lucency, which forms between the pneumonia and the chest wall. This lucency is round and has a smooth inner margin. The outer margin is produced by the interface between the area of pneumonia and the normal lung parenchyma. The sign is best seen in the frontal view, and is best visualized anterior to the heart. The "reverse hamburger bun sign" can be seen in the left upper lobe, right middle lobe, and right lower lobe, and is best seen in the setting of pneumonia and effusion.
